awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Social and Ecological Effects of Cattle Introduction
awd_abstract_narration:
When Europeans arrived to the Americas in the late 1500s, they introduced many organisms unknown to the "newly discovered" continent. The most impactful of these organisms was the domestic cow, the raising of which dramatically changed landscapes, animal management, and interactions among people. The biological consequence of the European colonialism, and in particular the introduction of cattle, constitutes a major event of human history that definitively shaped the modern world. In this study, archaeological remains of colonial period cattle are analyzed to better understand the effects of this introduction not only on the cattle themselves, but also on the development of the diverse colonial societies of Mesoamerica and the Caribbean during the two first centuries of Spanish rule. Archaeology, and more particularly zooarchaeology is particularly well placed to explore this topic because it provides a direct analysis of the fine-grained processes that affected the animals' biology and behavior but also how their management affected human social systems. Archaeological remains from five early colonial sites from Mexico, Guatemala, and Haiti, dating between the early 16th and the late 17th centuries, will be studied to identify the geographic origins of the animals (ancient DNA), their morphological diversity (skeletal morphometrics), and their demographic and health structure (age/sex and pathologies of the individuals within each population). Together these lines of evidence will provide an image of how the first colonists brought, traded and exchanged these animals. Cattle raising represented, and still represents in many regions of the Americas including the US, a crucial aspect of culture and economics. Studying the first steps of the implementation of cattle raising will shed a new light on the pivotal role played by domestic animals such as cattle in the early colonization of the Americas. This project is also a methodological contribution to the field by constituting the first use of combined archaeological genomics and morphological traits to document the history trajectory of colonial faunas in the Americas. Collaborations among US, Mexican and Guatemalan researchers, as well as lectures and museum exhibits will provide information and encourage discussion among the international audience of archaeologists, biologists, and cattle-owners. 

To address the question of how the transplantation and exploitation of cattle transformed both cattle and human populations in the Caribbean and Mesoamerica during the early Spanish colonial period, the research project will use three methodological approaches: (1) extraction and sequencing of ancient DNA from archaeological cow remains will clarify the origins and phylogeographic history of New World colonial cattle. (2) Geometric morphometric (GMM) data will define the regional and temporal variability of cow molar shape as a proxy for cattle morphotype diversity. These two lines of evidence will reveal the composition of the original populations of Spanish colonial cattle, highlight whether the animals were brought from Europe or Africa, and clarify the chronology of these introductions across the study region. (3) Finally, zooarchaeological markers of age and sex will document cattle herd demographics, and paleopathological indicators of health will illustrate the impact of diverse cattle husbandry practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Thanks to NSF funding, the project “Social and Ecological Effects of Cattle Introduction” NSF-BCS 1930628 (PI Emery, co-PI Delsol) has considerably advanced our knowledge of the process and impacts of the introduction of domestic cattle in the development of the early post-Columbian Americas. The research has revealed the complexity of cattle introductions and their vital role as a nexus of cultural interactions among Native Americans and colonists from both Europe and Africa. Delsol’s PhD research argues that not only did the introduction of cattle in the Americas play an important role in the implantation of European colonialism in the Western Hemisphere, the activities surrounding cattle import and management was enabled by the diverse peoples with which they interacted.

Delsol’s doctoral project aimed at investigating how the introduction, management, and exploitation of cattle transformed both cattle and human populations in the Caribbean and Mesoamerica during the early colonial period. With NSF support, we carried out this research by analyzing 8598 cattle zooarchaeological remains from 16 sites in four important colonial localities across the Circum-Caribbean region (the site of Puerto Real in Haiti, three sites in Mexico City and the site of la Ciudadela in Merida in Mexico, and 11 sites in and near the modern city of Antigua in Guatemala). This is the first regional zooarchaeological study to center-point colonial cattle as a proxy to analyze the sociocultural changes and continuities that characterized the colonial period in that region.

Our NSF funded investigation had two primary goals. (1) The first goal was to clarify the origins and provenience of the first herds of cattle introduced in the Western Hemisphere through the combination of archaeogenetic (aDNA) and geometric morphometric (GMM) analyses. (2) The second goal was to detail colonial cattle management practices through the assessment of the demographic structure of the herds (age, sex ratio, pathologies) based on osteometric and morphological observations.

(1) The results of the GMM analysis revealed a large variability in the shape of the elements, but variations that were consistent with those found in cattle of European/African ancestry (Bos taurus) rather than Asian cattle (Bos indicus). The ancient DNA of the mitochondrial genome revealed two important aspects of the early bovine populations in the Western Hemisphere. First, the findings contradicted the traditionally accepted history from documentary archives that the colonial stock originated from a small founding population originally brought to the Caribbean island of Hispaniola and traded from there to other Caribbean islands and to Mexico. Instead, the post-Columbian cattle tested in this sample presented a very diverse genetic makeup with specimens likely originating from many different sources in separate events, many directly from overseas. Second, our results strongly suggest that some animals were imported directly from Africa, beginning at least in the early 17th century, coincident with the rise of the Transatlantic slave trade between West Africa and the Americas. It is possible that some of the earliest colonial cattle may have arrived with African cattle herders who themselves could have had an important role in the management of the early cattle herds.

(2) Using osteological and osteometric observations on the zooarchaeological remains, we also analyzed cattle management practices at the different sites and compared these with known ethnographic examples of cattle bred for various purposes. The age at death profiles that suggest that in all sites a large majority of the slaughtered animals were very young adults, individuals who just had reached their final size. The second indicator, the sex ratio, was assessed through the statistical analysis of the size of the different cattle specimens in each site. Since cattle are sexually dimorphic (males are larger than females), this evidence revealed that in many sites, most of the animals slaughtered at a young age were males. Finally, we evaluated the animals’ health status through the study of paleopathological indicators. We found very few pathologies indicative of old age, confirming the results of the age-at-death studies. We also found that at all sites, lesions indicative of draft labor were very rare, suggesting that cattle were not regularly put to labor for plowing fields or pulling loaded carts. Together these lines of evidence suggest that open range ranching, a management practice that consisted of letting herds of cattle roam semi-freely over the landscape, is likely to have been practiced in many different regions from a very early date (early 16th century). In combination with the possibility of the introduction of cattle directly from Africa, and the known expertise of African cattle herders who also used free range cattle management techniques, this lends further support to the suggestion that Africans themselves may have had a vital role in the development of post-Columbian and early American cattle culture.
